intro: Corydalis alpestris var. calcarea, commonly known as the alpine corydalis, is a flowering plant native to mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that typically range in color from pink to purple. The plant has slender, hairy stems and produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain several seeds. It thrives in well-drained, rocky soils and is often found in alpine meadows and grasslands. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
